title: Why Hurricane Dorian Is So Hard to Track
text:
The constant shifting of Hurricane Dorian’s likely track prompted an official from the Federal Emergency Management Agency on Saturday to deem the Category 4 storm a “long-duration nail-biter.”

As of Saturday night, the center of the hurricane was on a projected trajectory to move northward in the coming days along the coast of Florida, Georgia and South Carolina, but without making a direct hit on the mainland.

The forecast was far different from just a couple of days earlier, when the storm was projected to make landfall somewhere around the midpoint of Florida’s eastern coast, before sweeping across the state and moving into the Gulf of Mexico. A later forecast had Dorian’s eye riding up Florida’s middle for a time, putting nearly the entire state on alert.

Dorian’s ultimate path is challenging to predict, meteorologists and hurricane researchers say, because the hurricane and others like it are guided by many ever-changing elements.

“They’re at the mercy of what’s happening around them,” said Matt Lanza, managing editor of Space City Weather, a blog that tracks hurricanes and weather in Texas and along the Gulf Coast. “I’m constantly amazed at just what one little, tiny change can do to the whole picture.”

Among the biggest factors are the pressure systems and wind currents, like the trade winds or the jet stream, that steer a storm.

Michael Mann, a climate scientist at Pennsylvania State University, said both were at play with Dorian, especially as it interacted with a high-pressure ridge over the western Atlantic. “It’s very difficult to predict, four or five days out, precisely how strong that ridge will be, where precisely it will be, and thus where precisely the storm will be directed.”

The amount of time a hurricane spends moving over warm surface water is also a factor. The warmer the water, the more intense a hurricane becomes.

“That’s the fuel to a hurricane,” said Lance Wood, meteorologist at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s National Hurricane Center.

As Dorian hits the Bahamas, expected sometime Sunday, forecasters predict the storm will decelerate and linger, slowing to just 2 miles per hour. That would be a devastating prospect for the islands.

“You get more rainfall, you get a longer period of time exposed to the wind and the surge,” Mr. Wood said.

Timothy Hall, a senior scientist at NASA’s Goddard Institute for Space Studies, said hurricanes appear to be slowing down and stalling more. He defined stalling as any storm that spends at least 48 hours in a 200-kilometer (124-mile) radius. Mr. Hall said it was hard to know why storms were stalling more frequently. “That’s where we’re at the edge of what we understand.”

Unless the models shift again, Dorian is expected to continue northward and make a turn toward the right.

Dr. Hall said just how much damage Dorian does to coastal communities will depend a lot on the timing of that turn.

“Is it going to do it before it makes landfall in Florida?” he asked. “A six- or eight- or 12-hour difference in when it makes the turn makes all the difference.”

Whatever Dorian does, federal officials cautioned those in the storm’s path to remain vigilant.

“It’s really critical that folks in the Carolinas down to central Florida continue to pay very close attention to Dorian, not get complacent, remain vigilant, and take action now,” David Bibo, deputy associate administrator for response and recovery at FEMA, said Saturday.

Write to Erin Ailworth at Erin.Ailworth@wsj.com
description: The ultimate path of Hurricane Dorian is challenging to predict, experts say, because the storm and others like it are guided by many ever-changing elements.
